name: Sample Campaign (Demo)
description: Example phishing emails demonstrating urgency, authority, and service impersonation techniques. Load this to explore Phish Monger's annotation and campaign features.

campaignPhishes.htmlSource:
Hi there,

Your account will be suspended in 24 hours unless you verify your credentials immediately.

Click here to sign in.

IT Support Team

lure-1.title: Urgency Timeline
lure-1.explanation: Creates false urgency with '24 hours' deadline to pressure you into acting without thinking. Legitimate IT support rarely uses such aggressive time pressure.

lure-2.title: Vague Call to Action
lure-2.explanation: Generic 'click here' link without showing the actual URL. This hides the malicious destination. Always hover over links to see where they really go.

campaignPhishes.htmlSource:
Hi,

I need you to send me the Q1 financial reports right away.

Working from home today and can't access the server. Just reply to this email with the files attached.

Thanks,
Sarah Johnson
CEO

lure-1.title: Unusual Executive Request
lure-1.explanation: Business Email Compromise (BEC) attack impersonating a CEO. Executives rarely ask employees to email sensitive financial reports directly. This is a common pattern for data theft.

lure-2.title: Spoofed Display Name
lure-2.explanation: The sender name 'Sarah Johnson' can be easily spoofed. The actual email address is likely fake or a compromised account. Always verify the sender's actual email address, not just the display name.

campaignPhishes.htmlSource:
Hello,

You have new document notifications waiting in your SharePoint account.

View documents now before they are automatically deleted.

Microsoft SharePoint Team

lure-1.title: Service Impersonation
lure-1.explanation: Impersonates SharePoint, a trusted service. The attackers want you to believe this is an automated notification from Microsoft. Note that Microsoft doesn't send emails threatening document deletion.

lure-2.title: Fear-Driven Action
lure-2.explanation: Creates fear of losing documents ('automatically deleted') to make you click without thinking. This exploits our natural aversion to loss. Real services don't delete notifications automatically.

campaignPhishes.htmlSource:
Dear Customer,

We overcharged you on your recent purchase. We've processed a refund of $247.50 to your account.

Click here to claim your refund within 48 hours or it will be cancelled.

Accounting Department

lure-1.title: Fake Reciprocity
lure-1.explanation: Creates a sense of obligation through a 'favor' - the refund. This makes you feel like you owe them something. The specific dollar amount adds credibility and makes it feel legitimate.

lure-2.title: Urgency + Curiosity
lure-2.explanation: Combines time pressure (48 hours) with the promise of free money. This creates emotional arousal that bypasses critical thinking. No legitimate refund requires you to click a link to claim it.
